hedline.hl1: Delivering the Mail And Helping the Police

abstract.p: Letter carriers in Maplewood, NJ, will be issued cellular phones to report suspicious circumstances, crimes in progress and fires or other emergencies (S)

block.p: Starting today, Maplewood's 59-member police force will have an additional 29 people in uniform walking a beat -- but they will not be officers.

In what officials say is a first for the region, letter carriers from the Maplewood Post Office will be issued cellular phones to report suspicious circumstances, crimes in progress, fires or other emergencies.

The phones, which are programmed to call only the police dispatch desk, were issued yesterday but had to be charged for 24 hours and will be ready for use this morning, said Paul Gizzo, Maplewood's police director, who helped established the program with a $10,000 Federal grant.

Frank Santora, a spokesman for the United States Postal Service, said the letter carriers were happy to lend their eyes and ears. ''We're out there everyday, everywhere,'' he said. ''Our people have very good knowledge of the community.''
